description: From Middle English mowen, mayen, moȝen, maȝen, from Old English magan, from Proto-West Germanic *magan, from Proto-Germanic *maganą, from Proto-Indo-European *megʰ-.

Cognate with Dutch mag (“may”, first and third-person singular of mogen (“to be able to, be allowed to, may”)), Low German mögen, German mag (“like”, first and third-person singular of mögen (“to like, want, require”)), Swedish må, Icelandic mega, megum. See also might.

verbs.description: may (third-person singular simple present may, no present participle, simple past might, no past participle)

entries.meaning: (obsolete, intransitive) To be strong; to have power (over). [8th–17th c.]
(obsolete, auxiliary) To be able; can. [8th–17th c.]
(intransitive, poetic) To be able to go. [from 9th c.]
(modal auxiliary verb, defective) To have permission to, be allowed. Used in granting permission and in questions to make polite requests. [from 9th c.]
examples: you may smoke outside;  may I sit there?

entries.meaning: (modal auxiliary verb, defective) Expressing a present possibility; possibly. [from 13th c.]
examples: he may be lying;  Schrödinger's cat may or may not be in the box

entries.meaning: (subjunctive present, defective) Expressing a wish (with present subjunctive effect). [from 16th c.]
examples: may you win;  may the weather be sunny

entries.meaning: Used in modesty, courtesy, or concession, or to soften a question or remark.

description: French mai, so called because it blossoms in the month of May.

entries.meaning: The hawthorn bush or its blossoms.

verbs.description: may (third-person singular simple present mays, present participle maying, simple past and past participle mayed)

entries.meaning: (poetic, intransitive) To gather may, or flowers in general.
